filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of the following works related to Blake’s development of his illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave: Preliminary Sketches for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Pencil Sketches; Preliminary Drawings for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Monochrome Wash Drawings; and Preliminary Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
In addition, we are republishing the following works, previously presented in our Preview mode, to make their designs fully searchable: Robert Blair, The Grave, the 1808 book listed under Commercial Book Illustrations, Designed by Blake and Engraved by Other Engravers; Deaths Door, listed under Separate Plates and Plates in Series, Designed and Engraved by Blake; and Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, the series of twenty finished designs, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
Taken together, these works in a variety of media present a comprehensive overview of one of Blake’s major projects as an illustrator and exemplify his working methods as he developed rough sketches into finished water colors. The evolution of any one design can be traced via links presented under Related Works in the Archive on the pull-down menus, lower left on the main viewing page for each work.
In October 1805, Blake was commissioned by the engraver and would-be publisher Robert H. Cromek to prepare forty drawings illustrating Robert Blair's The Grave, a popular "Graveyard" school poem first published in 1743. Cromek originally planned to select twenty of these designs for a deluxe edition of the poem. Blake launched into the project with great enthusiasm, rapidly sketching out his illustrations in pencil, developing some into wash drawings, and then producing a group of more finished water colors for presentation to Cromek. In a first prospectus of November 1805, Cromek names Blake as both the designer and engraver of fifteen designs. Blake etched one image, Deaths Door, in white-line, but Cromek rejected it. The dark power of the print appeals to modern tastes, but was far from fashionable in the early nineteenth century. In a second prospectus, also of November 1805, Cromek announced that Louis Schiavonetti would engrave twelve designs for the new edition. Blake had lost the potentially lucrative commission to engrave his own designs; his relationship with Cromek descended into anger and argument. In spite of their disagreement, Cromek included a portrait of Blake as a frontispiece to the volume, published in 1808. Cromek promoted the book aggressively and the illustrations to The Grave became Blake's best known work through much of the nineteenth century.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: Sketch for Robert Blair's "The Grave": 'Heaven's Portals Wide Expand to Let Him In'

objdescid.compdate: 1805The recto (Object 6) is a preliminary sketch for *Death of the Strong Wicked Man*, Object 8 among Blake's water color illustrations for Robert H. Cromek's edition of Robert Blair's *The Grave*. The verso (Object 7) is a preliminary sketch for *Heaven's Portals Wide Expand to Let Him In*, Object 13 among Blake's water color illustrations for Robert H. Cromek's edition of Robert Blair's *The Grave*. All four works can be dated to the fall of 1805. Luigi Schiavonetti's etching/engraving of the recto design was published in Cromek's 1808 edition; see Object 6 in the Archive. The verso design was not published.

objinfo.support: wove paperThe paper is from the 1802 edition of William Hayley, *Designs to a Series of Ballads*, as indicated by the partly erased letterpress word "run" visible on the recto, lower right, and the partly erased letterpress word "It" visible on the verso, upper right.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, in lot 200 or 201 with other works (2s. for lot 200 or 3s. for lot 201, both to the dealer Francis Harvey); George A. Smith, sold Christie's, 16 July 1880, in lot 118 with two other works by Blake (12s. to the dealer E. Parsons); sold by Parsons in 1881 to the Victoria and Albert Museum.

objnote.p: This sketch is a preliminary drawing for *Heaven's Portals Wide Expand to Let Him In*, Object 13 among Blake's water color illustrations for Robert H. Cromek's edition of Robert Blair's *The Grave*. The design was not published in Cromek's 1808 book.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three Gothic arches stand in the upper portion of the design, one at the center and two half arches seen on each side. Each arch is separated by a column. This may be the doorway to heaven. Beams of light radiate downward from the portal. In the center of the image floats a gowned figure, probably male and rising, seen from behind. In the water color of this design, this figure is Christ. His legs are together, with his left leg slightly bent and extended backward. His ankles may be crossed and both feet are on tiptoe. His arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms held vertically or upward. To the left of the central figure is a group of at least four gowned figures, facing away or to the right. They may be standing or hovering; perhaps they are even rising with the central figure. The leftmost figure of the group may be a child. The figure second from the left may have long hair or a veil over its head, implying that it is female. The two rightmost figures bend slightly left. The figure second from the right raised its left(?)arm vertically. To the right of the central figure is a group of at least five gowned figures, facing away or to the left. They may be standing or hovering; perhaps they are even ascending after the central figure. The leftmost figure extends its left leg backward, slightly bent, with its arms raised vertically, palms together, in a gesture of prayer or supplication. The figure second from the right may have long hair or a veil over her head. She may be holding an infant in her arms. The rightmost figure may be a child. A few lines below the feet of the main, central figure suggest more small figures, possibly standing, hovering, or rising and possibly gowned.
